name: Appium
tagline: Native iPhone app test automation with Appium
body:
### Welcome to Appium Pages.
This framework provides many valuable features for simplifying Selenium/Appium Web/Native Mobile app's testing. It simplifies the configuration and creation of Appium Driver for different platform. The framework also provides a Page abstraction for modeling your mobile/web app's pages.

##### Sample code creating a Mobile instance (Android) in PageObject/PageFactory

``` java     
public void loginTest(){
    mobile.loadTopLevelPage(LoginPage.class)
        .login();
```   
           
``` java            
protected MobileBrowser getAndroid() throws WebDriverException {
    return MobileBrowserBuilder.getAndroidBuilder("http://127.0.0.1:4723/wd/hub")
           .withTimeoutsConfig(timeouts())
           .withPlatformVersion("4.4")
           .withDeviceName("Moto X")
           .withApp("/Users/ssayem/IdeaProjects/Appium/src/test/resources/apps.apk")
           .withAppPackage("com.sayem.android")
           .withAppActivity("com.sayem.android.activities.HomeActivity")
           .build();
}
```
``` java                               
private TimeoutsConfig timeouts() {
    return TimeoutsConfig.builder()
           .pageLoadTimoutSeconds(10)
           .implicitWaitTimeoutMillis(20000)
           .build();
}                              
```             
Pages provide an abstraction for modeling the pages for your webapp.
Pages should extend BaseTopLevelPage or BaseSubPage.
Uses the Selenium @FindBy annotation to instantiate member variables that are WebElements.
Use the annotation @SubPageField to indicate a member variable that is a SubPage and should be instantiated on page load.
Model the actions that you can perform on your web pages in your Page classes.
Then, test code is incredibly simple. It just delegates to Page classes and performs high-level actions.
